fr.sii.ogham.email.builder

Class AutofillSubjectBuilder

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.sii.ogham.core.builder.AbstractParent<P>
      • fr.sii.ogham.core.builder.AbstractAutofillDefaultValueBuilder<AutofillSubjectBuilder,AutofillEmailBuilder>
        • fr.sii.ogham.email.builder.AutofillSubjectBuilder
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Builder<MessageFiller>, Parent<AutofillEmailBuilder>

    public class AutofillSubjectBuilder
extends AbstractAutofillDefaultValueBuilder<AutofillSubjectBuilder,AutofillEmailBuilder>
implements Builder<MessageFiller>
    Configures how to handle missing Email subject: if no subject is explicitly defined on the Email, Ogham will use the result of this builder configuration to provide a default subject. Default subject can be provided by:
    • Using HTML <title> header tag as subject
    • Using first line text if prefixed
    • Using a property value
    Author:
    Aur√©lien Baudet

      • AutofillSubjectBuilder

        public AutofillSubjectBuilder(AutofillEmailBuilder parent,
                              EnvironmentBuilder<?> environmentBuilder)
        Initializes with the parent builder and the EnvironmentBuilder. The parent builder is used when calling the AbstractParent.and() method. The EnvironmentBuilder is used by build() method to evaluate property values.
        Parameters:
        parent - the parent builder
        environmentBuilder - configuration about property resolution

    • Method Detail

      • htmlTitle

        public AutofillSubjectBuilder htmlTitle(boolean enable)
        Enable/disable using HTML <title> tag to provide a subject on the Email if none was explicitly defined.
        Parameters:
        enable - true to enable, false to disable
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • text

        public AutofillSubjectBuilder text(String... firstLinePrefixes)
        Uses first line of text template to define the email subject (only if a prefix is defined). You can specify a direct value. For example: 
         .text("Subject:");

        You can also specify one or several property keys. For example: 

         .text("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}");
        The properties are not immediately evaluated. The evaluation will be done when the build() method is called. If you provide several property keys, evaluation will be done on the first key and if the property exists (see EnvironmentBuilder), its value is used. If the first property doesn't exist in properties, then it tries with the second one and so on.
        Parameters:
        firstLinePrefixes - one value, or one or serveral property keys
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • provider

        public AutofillSubjectBuilder provider(SubjectProvider provider)
        Extension point to provide any additional subject provider. See SubjectProvider for more information. If defined, any previously defined configuration is not used. Only one provider can be defined. So you may need to register a FirstSupportingSubjectProvider with the list of your custom providers.
        Parameters:
        provider - the provider to use
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining
